Award.AwardTitle: Ideal Probe Single Molecule Imaging for the Study of Small Molecule and Polymeric Glass Formers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Laura Kaufman of Columbia University is using advanced imaging techniques to study how molecules move in a class of materials known as glass formers. Glass formers may exist as supercooled liquids or glasses, materials that demonstrate unusual and poorly understood behaviors at both the microscopic and macroscopic scales. These materials are ubiquitous in nature and in modern technology, present in window glass, plastics, and medications delivered as pills and tablets. Understanding how molecules move in these systems not only addresses fundamental questions but also enhances understanding of how to stabilize these materials against various types of degradation. The PI develops and uses single molecule imaging approaches to detail the rotations and translations of molecules in these systems, teasing out key time scales and length scales related to molecular motions and relaxations in these environments.

The single molecule imaging experiments in supercooled liquids underway employ newly designed and synthesized ideal probe molecules; these are probes that do not average in space or time over heterogeneities in a glassy host. As a result, these probes directly interrogate length and time scales of interest in these systems and test predictions of theories of the glass transition. The experiments detail dynamic heterogeneity as manifested in relaxation and exchange time distributions of rotational dynamics in both small molecule and polymeric glass formers. In addition, experiments that require sub-diffraction localization are being performed to follow translational dynamics and structural rearrangements in supercooled liquids to resolve questions regarding the poorly understood phenomenon of rotational-translational decoupling. Related techniques employing two types of probes are employed to measure dynamic correlations, allowing identification of length scales of heterogeneity in supercooled liquids. Ideal probe single molecule measurements are also being performed in thin polymeric films, with a focus on identifying the putative surface mobile layer that has practical ramifications for the stability of thin film devices and vapor-deposited glasses. To complement studies of glassy systems prepared through cooling, studies of such systems prepared through swelling are also underway. These studies both detail aspects of dynamic heterogeneity and directly visualize structural rearrangements underlying long time scale relaxations in these systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have studied the motion of molecules in small molecule and polymeric glass formers, materials that can be cooled below their freezing temperature without transforming into a crystalline solid. Instead, such materials enter a supercooled state in which their structure remains very similar to that in normal liquids but the motion of molecules slows abruptly as the temperature is decreased, approaching that in crystalline solids. Molecular motion in these systems is not only slow, it is also unusual, with indications of a phenomenon known as dynamic heterogeneity, in which some sets of molecules move much faster than others just nanometers away. We have continued study of molecular motion in these systems, with a focus on using single molecule probe molecules that can report on the dynamical behavior of the supercooled liquid molecules in their vicinity. During the period of this grant award, advances were made in the form of new probe molecules and new techniques to distinguish spatial and temporal heterogeneity in these systems. The experiments successfully completed identified ?ideal probe molecules? ? these are probes that do not average in space or time over heterogeneities in a host and can thus directly interrogate length and time scales of interest in these systems. Such probe molecules may not be ideal in all hosts, and we showed how simple approaches could be used to assess probe ideality before time intensive experiments were undertaken. We then used such probe molecules to characterize time scales associated with relaxation and dynamic exchange in both small molecule and polymeric glass formers. Finally, experiments that track probe translational dynamics and structural rearrangements were performed to characterize the poorly understood phenomena of Debye-Stokes-Einstein breakdown and rotational-translational decoupling in supercooled liquids. These measurements revealed that rotational-translational decoupling can exist on a single molecule level. Finally, an experimental setup for the study of glassy systems prepared through solvent swelling was built and studies in which behaviors of such systems are compared to those controlled through temperature are proceeding.

 

The experiments undertaken clarified aspects of supercooled liquid behavior that could not be addressed by ensemble experiments. The work also had educational impact on graduate student and postdoctoral researchers in the PI?s laboratory as well as on younger students. Six doctoral students were supported by and worked at least in part on the work funded by this grant award. Additionally, one student in a Bridge-to-PhD program was supported in part by this award. This program, originally funded jointly by Columbia University and the National Science Foundation, brings students from underrepresented groups and/or underprivileged backgrounds to Columbia for two years of academic study (bridging undergraduate and graduate courses) and an immersive two year research experience. This program helps retain students in STEM and broadens the pipeline of STEM researchers. The PI also participated in a successful proposal to the American Chemical Society to make Columbia?s Chemistry department a partner for their independent Bridge program, which also works to broaden the pipeline. The PI helped develop experiential learning experiences based on soft matter and food chemistry that were piloted at local events and in some cases integrated into General Chemistry laboratory classes, work that was accelerated upon the forced change to remote classes that occurred in Spring 2020 and lasted throughout the 2020-2021 academic year. This work both enhanced the curriculum and broadened interest in chemical topics among younger students.
